docs.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, animal welfare research was largely dismissed by farmers and food producers. But in the past few years, under pressure from animal rights advocates and consumers concerned about the rapid growth of mega-farms, some of the world's biggest food companies, including McDonald's, Wendy's and Tyson Foods, have begun to hire animal welfare specialists. These consultants are helping the companies adopt new standards for the humane treatment and slaughter of livestock in food factories that often house tens of thousands of hogs, chickens and cattle.

headline.main: Word for Word/Animal Welfare Studies; Pig Massage and Helping Ducks Preen: Who Says We're Heartless Carnivores?

docs.abstract: Treatment and slaughter of livestock are focus of growing amount of research, all intended to improve welfare of farm animals, but benefits to be derived from some studies are not all that obvious, at least to untrained eye; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: FOR decades, animal welfare research was largely dismissed by farmers and food producers. But in the past few years, under pressure from animal rights advocates and consumers concerned about the rapid growth of mega-farms, some of the world's biggest...

docs.lead_paragraph: Telling people they are H.I.V.-positive is the only thing about my job I don't like. People's reactions vary. A lot of people shut down; they start to space out; they want to bolt. We can't make them stay and talk with us about how they are feeling and what the next steps are, but that is what we try to do. I do H.I.V. testing at H.O.P.E. Inc., a clinic in Tulsa, Okla. In my six years doing this, I've had some people become very upset, because they were pretty certain about who infected them. They said they were going to attack the person. In one case, a client started screaming about how he was going to go kill his partner. But the people who react the most strongly are those who don't consider themselves to be in the ''high risk'' groups. When those people are positive, it's a lot to deal with. Until recently, there was a two-week wait before the results came in. But in the past few months, we have started using the new OraQuick test, which gives the patient a result in around 20 minutes. There are so many good things about the new test. We deal with a lot of the high-risk people who have unstable lives; there is a good chance they are not going to come back for their result. With OraQuick, we don't have to worry. On the other hand, we are right in the room with the client when we get the results. Sometimes, a result shows up in 5 or 10 minutes. You have no idea how stressful it is to know that someone is positive while you are sitting in front of him or her. It would be a lot easier if you could just tell them the information as soon as you know, but you have to give the test 20 minutes to work.
docs.abstract: Jeremy Simmons Lives article on his work doing HIV testing and counseling in Tulsa, Okla, clinic; cites difficulty of telling patients they are infected with AIDS virus, particularly people who do not think they are in 'high risk' group; notes quick new test gives him no time to prepare (M).

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 48, with two children in secondary school, my childbearing years are, happily, over. Yet during a recent visit to Ford Division headquarters here, memories of pregnancy came awkwardly flooding back: the bloated midsection, the aching back, the clumsy gait. Who got me in this fix?

headline.main: To Complete the Pregnancy Experience, Just Add Some Pickles and Ice Cream

docs.abstract: Ford Motor Co has asked its engineers and designers working on vehicles frequently driven by women to wear so-called Empathy Belly Pregnancy Simulator to get sense of pregnant women's needs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Amina Lawal, the Nigerian peasant woman whose case became known worldwide after she was sentenced to death by stoning for adultery, was acquitted today by the highest Islamic court in her state. A roar of approval swept through the small, sweltering courtroom when a five-member panel of judges ruled 4 to 1 to overturn Ms. Lawal's conviction in a case that had heaped worldwide opprobrium on Nigeria, Africa's most populous country and one in which the split between Muslims and Christians has become increasingly sharp.

headline.main: Facing Death for Adultery, Nigerian Woman Is Acquitted

docs.abstract: Highest Islamic court in Katsina State in Nigeria acquits Amina Lawal, peasant woman whose case became known worldwide after she was sentenced to death by stoning for adultery; case had heaped worldwide opprobrium on Nigeria, where split between Muslims and Christians has become increasingly sharp; Lawal had been sentenced under Shariah, or Islamic law; her defense team argued that death by stoning is not allowed under Nigerian Constitution; latest ruling relieves Pres Olusegun Obasanjo, born-again Christian, from having to intervene directly; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Amina Lawal, the Nigerian peasant woman whose case became known worldwide after she was sentenced to death by stoning for adultery, was acquitted today by the highest Islamic court in her state.    A roar of approval swept through the small,...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the venerable Hollywood weepie ''Love Story'' -- or at least in the Mad magazine parody of it -- Ali McGraw suffered from a fatal disease that made her more beautiful as it progressed. Judging from ''My Life Without Me,'' a new indie weepie that opens today in New York and Los Angeles, three decades of medical progress have failed to wipe out this terrible, mysterious malady. Sarah Polley, the pale, radiant young Canadian actress who has also starred in Atom Egoyan's ''Sweet Hereafter'' and ''Exotica'' and Hal Hartley's ''No Such Thing,'' grows simultaneously paler and more radiant as her character grows sicker. This bolsters two of the film's principal conceits, which might otherwise be a little shaky: that dying is a voyage of self-fulfillment, and that terminal illness can and should be kept secret until the last minute. Ms. Polley plays Ann, a 23-year-old mother of two who works on the night cleaning crew at the local university and lives with her husband, Don (Scott Speedman), in a trailer in her mother's back yard. The mother, played by the estimable Deborah Harry, is a study in working-class bitterness, and Ann's own biography, related in voice-over narration, has the ring of blue-collar boilerplate: teenage pregnancy, a father in jail, a husband who has trouble finding work. And then everything changes: at the hospital after a fainting spell, Ann learns that she has only a few months to live. Rather than tell her family, she decides to brave this terrible situation alone -- not just to make the best of her sickness, but to make it the best thing that ever happened to her.

headline.main: With Just a Few Months to Live, A Lifetime of Changes to Make

docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie My Life Without Me, directed by Isabel Coixet; Sarah Polley and Scott Speedman star; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, a California teenager died at a hospital in Pleasanton, just days after taking prescription pills to abort her early pregnancy. The circumstances surrounding her death are unclear, and an autopsy is under way. But battle lines are already being drawn, with opponents of abortion saying the death of the woman, Holly Patterson, 18, shows why the abortion pills are too dangerous to remain on the market, while abortion providers say it shows no such thing.

headline.main: Death at 18 Spurs Debate Over a Pill For Abortion

docs.abstract: Battles lines form as autopsy is performed on Holly Patterson, 18-year-old California woman who died week after taking mifepristone at Planned Parenthood clinic to abort her early pregnancy; abortion opponents say death shows that abortion pills are too dangerous to remain on market; abortion providers say it shows no such thing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kate Michelman said today that she would step down as president of Naral Pro-Choice America, ending 18 years at the helm of the country's most vocal group advocating abortion as a legal right for women. Ms. Michelman, 61, became one of the grandes dames of the reproductive rights debate by interpreting her mandate broadly. She campaigned for state and national politicians who supported abortion rights, testified at Congressional hearings, started national advertising campaigns, worked to expand access to clinics providing abortions, and protested and marched in the streets.

headline.main: Head of Group Backing Right To Abortion Is to Resign

docs.abstract: Kate Michelman to step down next Apr as president of Naral Pro-Choice America, ending 18 years as head of vocal group advocating abortion as legal right for women; expresses concern that opponents are gaining ground, interview; photo (M)
